FuncDef:
The nat no-pat enhance command enables no-PAT conversion for all IP packets.
The undo nat no-pat enhance command restores the default configuration.
By default, no-PAT conversion is enabled for packets of TCP/UDP/PPTP ALG for GRE/ICMP and disabled for the other IP packets.
ExtraInfo:
Usage Scenario
No-PAT conversion takes effect only on packets of TCP, UDP, ICMP, and PPTP ALG for GRE. To enable no-PAT conversion for all IP packets, run the nat no-pat enhance command.
Configuration Impact
After this command is run, the no-PAT conversion mode is supported only in this instance, and the PAT and no-PAT address pools cannot be simultaneously configured.
Precautions
The nat no-pat enhance command can be run only in NAT444 instances.
If the nat pure-ip-packet drop command is run in the system view and the nat no-pat enhance command is run in the NAT444 instance view, the nat pure-ip-packet drop command does not take effect.The
nat no-pat enhance command is mutually exclusive with the following commands in NAT444 instances:
exclude-portl2-aware enablenat address-group over-loadnat address-group unnumbered interfacenat address-group bind-ip-poolnat alarm port-number user enablenat bind static-mappingnat ip access-user limitnat port-limit enablenat statistics port-usage enableport-forwarding address-groupport-rangeport-single enablenat port-usage load-balance enablenat server-mode enablenat server protocol unnumbered interfacenat server protocol (The nat no-pat enhance command is mutually exclusive with this command that only configures the interface-level internal server function.)
After the nat no-pat enhance command is run, the following commands can be run but do not take effect:
nat alarm port-number address-group disablenat alarm address-group port-number thresholdnat alarm user port-number thresholdnat port-limit
